>4) How will you deal with the stochastic evaluation situation created by
>module-module co-evolution. Consider this case: two modules (A and B)
>compose network X. Under your algorithm (if I understand correctly) A gets
>an evolution phase, B gets an evolution phase, and then X evolves one
>generation. So now when we come back to A's evolution phase, the
>population fitness rankings may have completely changed, because fitness
>is dependent on B's evolution is well. In modular NEAT this proved to be
>the biggest weak point in the algorithm, since it yielded no real module
>evolution (if you read the paper: modules evolved to be /highly/
>generalist, and then it turned out that only bindings really mattered for
>fitness).

This depends a great-deal on what type of modules you are attempting to 
implement.  Remember the discussion of "modularity and interfaces" from 
earlier in the year (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/message/1871).  If 
the modules were just encoded by parts of the genome, then no fitness 
separate from the fitness of the whole would be required (just as, even 
though the same gene might be present in multiple genomes, there's no need 
to try to calculate a cross-population fitness for it).

In fact, even if the modules are not contained in the genome, if they are 
simply inherited from the genomes parent(s) then they will act as if they 
were contained in the genome.  In this case, the only special handling 
required would be to delete a module once no genomes reference it.

I have the impression you are considering some scheme which tries to 
calculate the fitness of individual modules.  Presumably so that you can 
vary the frequency of the modules in the population accordingly?  A scheme 
like this comes up against the "credit assignment problem" which is a 
fundamental problem of AI and insoluble in the general case ((because 
understanding the allocation of an algorithm's success/failure amongst the 
parts of the algorithm is at least as complex as the algorithm itself; and 
thus at least as complex as the solution to the (presumably general) 
problem you are setting it)).

However, in the specific case here, one can calculate instantaneous, 
relative fitnesses for different alleles of the same module.  The fitnesses 
won't carry over to a context where the module's usage has changed (e.g. 
another generation).  And it won't allow comparison with a different 
module.  What you would need to do would be to hold the rest of the system 
constant, and try every allele of the module in every genome (or at least 
all the genomes which use this module).  The difference in the average 
fitness of the population when using module-1 allele-1 and when using 
module-1, allele-2 is the instantaneous difference in the fitness of those 
two alleles.

However, I wonder if such an approach is useful.  Examining the 
instantaneous fitness is akin to using a steepest descents approach -- e.g. 
it looks at one point on the fitness surface and chooses a (OK stochastic) 
direction based on the point.  Also this type of module fitness provides no 
information about the insertion of modules into genomes, or the choice of 
module type (as opposed to allele) when the insertion happens -- so its 
only helping with a small part of the problem.

         Ian
